[[Jimmy Johnson (blues guitarist)|Jimmy Johnson]] |website = }} '''Syl Johnson''' (born July 1, 1936) is an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] and [[soul music|soul]] [[singer]] and [[record producer]]. ==Biography== Born '''Sylvester Thompson''' in [[Holly Springs, Mississippi]], United States, he migrated with his family to Chicago in 1950; blues guitarist [[Magic Sam]] was his next-door neighbor.{{cite web|last=Ward|first=Ed|title=The 'Complete Mythology' Of Syl Johnson|url=http://www.npr.org/2011/08/25/139919009/the-complete-mythology-of-syl-johnson|publisher=NPR|accessdate=16 February 2012}} Johnson sang and played with blues artists Magic Sam, [[Billy Boy Arnold]], [[Junior Wells]] and [[Howlin' Wolf]] in the 1950s, before recording with [[Jimmy Reed]] for [[Vee-Jay]] in 1959. He made his solo debut that same year with [[Federal Records|Federal]], a subsidiary of [[King Records (USA)|King Records]] of Cincinnati, backed by [[Freddie King]] on guitar. He then began recording for [[Twilight/Twinight Records|Twinight Records]] of Chicago in the mid-1960s. Beginning with his first hit, "Come On Sock It to Me" in 1967, Johnson dominated the label as both a hitmaker and producer. His song "Different Strokes", also from 1967, featured on the ''[[Ultimate Breaks and Beats]]'' [[breakbeat]] [[compilation album|compilation]]. Like other black songwriters of the period, several of his records at this time explored themes of African-American identity and social problems as in songs including "Is It Because I'm Black", which reached Number 11 in the US ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] [[record chart|chart]] in 1969. In 1971, [[Willie Mitchell (musician)|Willie Mitchell]] brought Johnson to [[Hi Records]], the two recording three albums which spawned a number of singles. Produced in [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]] with the Hi house band, these yielded the hits "We Did It", "Back for a Taste of Your Love" and "Take Me to the River", his biggest success, reaching Number 7 on the R&B chart in 1975. However, at Hi Records, Johnson was always to some extent in [[Al Green]]'s shadow commercially, if not artistically. Mitchell also chose to use mainly in-house material rather than Johnson originals.{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}} After the Hi years ended, Johnson produced two LPs for his own Shama label, the latter of which (''Ms. Fine Brown Frame'', 1982) was picked up for distribution by [[Boardwalk Records]] and produced Johnson's last hit record, the title cut. Around the mid-1980s, Johnson started a fast-food fish restaurant business, and became semi-retired from performing, only making occasional appearances at blues club gigs.Liner notes to album ''Back in the Game'' by Robert Pruter In 1992, Johnson found out that his song "Different Strokes" had been [[sampling (music)|sampled]] by number of [[rapping|rappers]] including [[Wu-Tang Clan]], [[Public Enemy (band)|Public Enemy]], [[Kool G Rap]], [[MC Hammer|Hammer]], and the [[Geto Boys]]. Stimulated by this fact, he decided to make a comeback in the [[music industry]]. In 1994, he released the album ''Back in the Game'' on [[Delmark Records]]. The album featured the Hi rhythm section and his youngest daughter [[Syleena Johnson]]. Johnson has become one of the most sampled artists, largely from "Different Strokes" and "Is It Because I'm Black"; he feels passionately that taking music from an original artist without proper compensation constitutes theft{{cite web|last=Hoffer|first=Jason|title=Interview Continued With Blues/Soul Legend Syl Johnson - Come on, sock it to me S02Ep01 (2 of 3)|url=http://goingthruvinyl.com/?p=1496|work=S02Ep1-2-of-3-Syl-Johnson-Come-on-sock-it-to-me.mp3|publisher=Going Thru Vinyl|accessdate=16 June 2012|coauthors=Syl Johnson|location=12:25|format=.mp3 audio}} and has sued for copyright infringement.{{cite web|last=Gardner|first=Eriq Gardner|title=Kanye West and Jay-Z Sued for Allegedly Sampling Syl Johnson|url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/industry/legal-and-management/kanye-west-and-jay-z-sued-for-allegedly-1005416982.story|publisher=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=16 June 2012}}{{cite web|last=Mlynar|first=Phillip|title=Interviews Q&A: Soul Singer Syl Johnson Prefers Money To Women, Loves Being Sampled By The Wu-Tang Clan, And Is Sorry He Had To Sue Cypress Hill|url=http://blogs.villagevoice.com/music/2010/12/syl_johnson.php|publisher=The Village Voice|accessdate=16 June 2012}} Adding to Syl's famous family are his brothers, Blues guitarist and singer [[Jimmy Johnson (blues guitarist)|Jimmy Johnson]] and bassist Mack Thompson. Syl Johnson recently appeared on an episode of TV ONE's "R&B Divas," which starred his daughter Syleena Johnson. In the episode Syl is giving Syleena advice and words of encouragement before one of her live performances. ==Discography== ===Albums=== * 1968: ''Dresses Too Short'' (Twinight) * 1970: ''Is It Because I'm Black?''
